description: Dive into "Capture Lausanne: A Photographer's Paradise" — a handpicked list of places with quick notes, links, and essentials for fast trip planning and discovery.
title: Capture Lausanne: A Photographer's Paradise

places.generalDescription: Lausanne Cathedral, consecrated in 1275, is a stunning Gothic masterpiece that has been an important landmark in Switzerland since medieval times. The exterior of the cathedral is impressive with its ornate painted portal, belfry, and vibrant rose window. Inside, visitors can admire the grand organs, 13th-century choir stalls, and ancient stained glass windows. It also serves as a stop for pilgrims following the Camino de Santiago within Switzerland.

sources.snippet: The city’s solemn cathedral went up during the 13th century and was consecrated in 1275. That sound in the dead of night is the Lookout, who barks out the hours between 22:00 and 02:00 365 days a year and one of the last of his kind in Europe. One of the people to thank for the cathedral’s current appearance is the French master restorer Viollet-le-Duc.
sources.shortName: 15 Best Things to Do in Lausanne (Switzerland)

sources.snippet: Lausanne Cathedral stands tall as a Gothic masterpiece, captivating visitors with its intricate architecture and rich history. Built in the 12th century, this iconic structure has stood the test of time, bearing witness to centuries of religious and cultural significance. As one steps inside, the grandeur of the cathedral is truly awe-inspiring.
sources.shortName: Discover Lausanne'S Most Photogenic Spots With A Local

sources.snippet: Imagine yourself ascending the Escaliers du Marché, a winding wooden stairway that leads to the dramatic bell tower of the Cathedral. Explore the charming Rôtillon Quarter with its picturesque alleys and bohemian shops. And don't miss out on the stunning views from the Quais d'Ouchy, where you can capture the beauty of Lake Geneva.
sources.shortName: Explore the Instaworthy Spots of Lausanne with a Local

sources.snippet: A visit to this Gothic cathedral, which is also referred to as the Cathedral of Notre Dame of Lausanne, is one of the best things to do in Lausanne. This cathedral dates back to 1170. When the cathedral was first built, it was filled with ornate decorations and statues.
sources.shortName: Top Ten Things to do in Lausanne, Switzerland

places.name: Lausanne Cathedral

reviews.text: Lausanne Cathedral is absolutely stunning, both day and night. Sitting high in the old city, it feels massive and full of history. We went just before mass, and the atmosphere was so peaceful-plus, the people there were really friendly, which made it even better. The stained-glass windows are incredible, bursting with color when the light hits them. And at night, the whole place glows beautifully, making it just as impressive as during the day. Definitely a place that stays with you!

I highly recommend talking a walk up through the old town to the cathedral. It's free, and a beautiful building with lots to see. You'll also get some great views of Lausanne from the front. If you want even better views you can pay a small fee and climb the bell-tower. This gives you 360 degree views of the city. Absolutely epic on a clear day. It's not for the faint-hearted or those with vertigo. Also not for those with major mobility problems. I use a walking stick due to bone spurs in my ankle and I made it OK. Just had to take it a bit slower.

Impressive cathedral with wonderful views of the town. A bit of a climb up steps if one takes the wrong route, but in any case well worth a visit. Large, quiet, peaceful, stained glass, statues, carvings, small and unobtrusive gift shop. Not overly commercial, and free to enter, as it should be but in some churches is not. Panoramic views of the town below.

places.address: Pl. de la Cathédrale 1, 1005 Lausanne, Switzerland

places.generalDescription: The Olympic Museum in Lausanne is not your typical art museum, but it offers a unique blend of sports history, technology, and art. Situated in the city that houses the International Olympic Committee, this museum showcases sculptures and interactive multimedia displays dedicated to the Olympic Games. It's a must-visit for art and culture enthusiasts. The recently refurbished museum provides an interactive and educational experience, featuring artifacts, history, Olympic torches, posters, equipment, and clothing.

sources.snippet: * One of the most noteworthy facts about Lausanne* is its role in the global movement of professional sports. This picturesque city has been a constant base for the International Olympic Committee since 1914!. One of the places to see in Lausanne if you are an avid fan of everything sports-related in the Olympic Museum, where you will be able to make a memorable image with you and the eternal Olympic flame.
sources.shortName: 12 Instagrammable places in Lausanne

sources.snippet: We already mentioned that Lausanne is home to international organizations, most notably to the International Olympic Committee and the Olympic museum. This museum shows vintage equipment, medals, and other items and stories relating to the Olympic games. Next to the museum is the Olympic Garden which houses unique sculptures relating to sports.
sources.shortName: 15 Best Things To Do in Lausanne, Switzerland

sources.snippet: Lausanne is home to the Olympic Museum, a tourist and cultural landmark that also offers excellent photo opportunities. The elegant architectural lines and open spaces are fascinating subjects for photographers in search of beautiful compositions. For the full Olympic experience, go and see the IOC headquarters a bit further along the lakeside.
sources.shortName: In Lausanne, (even) the lens thrives: my best photo spots – Lausanne Tourisme

sources.snippet: As the home city to the International Olympic Committee, Lausanne is essentially the Olympic Capital. So it’s apt that you can get the inside track on one of the world’s great sporting events. The museum is south of the centre at Ouchy, commanding a view over Lake Geneva from the top of the Olympic Park.
sources.shortName: 15 Best Things to Do in Lausanne (Switzerland)

sources.snippet: Located in Lausanne, the Olympic Museum is a captivating tribute to the greatness of sports. This iconic museum showcases the rich history and inspiring stories of athletes who’ve participated in the Olympic Games. Here are three reasons why the Olympic Museum is a must-visit destination:
sources.shortName: Discover Lausanne'S Most Photogenic Spots With A Local

sources.snippet: One of the best things to do in Lausanne and a top tourist spot, the Olympic Museum, features exhibits related to the Olympics and sports. The facility houses over 10,000 artifacts and is considered the largest museum of its kind globally.
sources.shortName: Top 12 Best Things to Do in Lausanne, Switzerland

sources.snippet: This museum, which opened in 1993, is the largest archive of Olympic Games in the world. It is filled with interactive exhibits, short films, and Olympic artifacts. The highlight for us was the room filled with all of the Olympic torches.
sources.shortName: Top Ten Things to do in Lausanne, Switzerland

sources.snippet: Relive Olympic moments at the Olympic Museum and descend the picturesque Escaliers du Marche from the cathedral into Place de la Palud for sightseeing in the winding streets of the old city.
sources.shortName: Attractions & Things to Do in Lausanne

places.name: The Olympic Museum

reviews.text: The Olympic Museum in Lausanne, Switzerland, is a place where you can learn all about the Olympic Games. It shows the history of the Games, from the very first Olympics to today. The museum has many cool things like Olympic medals, torches, uniforms, and photos of famous athletes. You can see displays that explain how the Olympics started, the athletes' journeys, and the values of the Games, like fair play and friendship. There are also fun, interactive activities to get involved with. The museum is located near Lake Geneva, with beautiful views of the water and mountains. It's a great place for anyone interested in sports and the spirit of the Olympics.

We had a fantastic experience here. I never thought that this would actually be a good museum that I would enjoy seeing because I assumed it was all about the games, but watching the history and seeing the interactivity of all of the different exhibits, this was really really good well worth the money and the Front Desk guy was really nice and I had some sort of ticket to something else so I was able to get a minimal discount and this was a really nice way to spend an afternoon.

I did not need to buy tickets in advance and even the lobby is gorgeous so unless you're waiting a long time, it was fine looking around there

We were here in early July and it was a nice walk along the lake to this museum perched on a small hill in the middle of a lovely park. Please visit the grounds even if you do not step inside the museum.  Nice views over the lake and pleasant outdoor Olympic related art and information sprinkled through the outdoor grounds and all of this is free to access. Inside it is a well curated place with lots of information for an Olympics fan. We did it all in about 2 hours. The gift shop is where you buy the entrance tickets.

Pro tip: if you do have a ticket and are there during the daytime, you do NOT need a lunch reservation to simply have a drink on their glorious outdoor terrace at the restaurant on the top floor. We just asked the host if we could sit outside for a drink and he enthusiastically said of course! What views!!! Drinks were not cheap but not more expensive than any other restaurant. So if you are curious and didn't make a lunch reservation, please do stop by and see if you can snag a seat outside. The staff were kind and helpful.

places.generalDescription: AQUATIS Aquarium-Vivarium is a captivating destination that showcases the diverse ecosystems of five continents, featuring remarkable creatures such as Komodo dragons and crocodiles. Situated in Switzerland, known as Europe's freshwater reservoir, this attraction offers an immersive journey through the evolution of species and prehistoric animals. Visitors can explore African and Asian crocodiles, vipers, and delve into the rich flora and fauna of the Amazon forest.

sources.snippet: Aquatis is the biggest Aquarium-Vivarium in the entire continent of Europe and is located in one of the most vibrant cities, Lausanne. The aquarium opened up in September of 2010, and it consists of an area of 3.500 square meters with 46 aquariums, vivariums, and terrariums. Over 10.000 species of fish and over 100 species of reptiles live inside this aquarium.
sources.shortName: 15 Best Things To Do in Lausanne, Switzerland

places.name: AQUATIS Aquarium-Vivarium

reviews.text: The aquatium is one of its kind, where you get to know a lot about different sea creatures in a fun and interactive way. The aquarium has different sections focusing on different species, but the way it is designed it very interesting. One can easily take close to 2hours to cover the entire area. It is very well maintained and you have an option of half price ticket after 5pm, but the aquarium closes at 6pm, so 1hour wont be enough time to explore it properly. But still a must visit with kids/family/friends if you happen to be in Lausanne.

This is the only aquarium of its type in Switzerland where you can study various species that live in and around fresh water on all continents of our planet. I made the mistake to visit a dull and rainy Saturday afternoon end of March 2025 when the place was filled up by families with small children that have come from all over the country. This takes away much of the concentration and time needed to study was is on display. Things are extremely well organized and if you come from far away there is a hotel beside the aquarium complex. On Saturdays, parking is free which slightly reduces the rather elevated cost of visiting. If you want to spend time here with some peace of mind, avoid week-ends and Wednesday afternoons when children are off from school.

This Aquarium was absolutely beautiful! the tanks were all very clean and the environments were enriching for both the viewer and the animals. The space was pretty big and well laid out I had a great day here!

places.generalDescription: Esplanade de Montbenon is a picturesque park in Lausanne, Switzerland, offering stunning views of Lake Geneva and the surrounding Alps. The site features a statue of William Tell, known for its legendary hero equipped with a crossbow. This expansive terrace provides an extraordinary range of environments along a flat stretch covering over half a kilometer. Visitors can enjoy leisurely strolls and picnics in well-manicured gardens while taking in the breathtaking city and lake views.

sources.snippet: If you want to see the surroundings of Lausanne, the picturesque panoramas of Lake Geneva and the Alpine peaks, come to the city park of Montbenon. On the esplanade there are a lot of restaurants, many well-appointed areas for recreation and walks. On warm days there are large-scale jazz concerts.
sources.shortName: Top 21 places to visit in Lausanne in 2024 (Lots of photos)

sources.snippet: So we know that Lausanne is blessed with exhilarating panoramas. But the one at Esplanade de Montbenon rivals the best in the city. In this manicured, verdant space you’ll be inclined just to sit and stare at the scenery.
sources.shortName: 15 Best Things to Do in Lausanne (Switzerland)

sources.snippet: For a more laid-back tourist spot, the Esplanade de Montbenon is a city park ideal for family picnics and watching the sunset. The park is at the heart of Lausanne, overlooking Lake Geneva and the surrounding Alps.
sources.shortName: Top 12 Best Things to Do in Lausanne, Switzerland

sources.snippet: Enjoy stunning views, a romantic fountain, a lush park, and majestic buildings like the Swiss Film Archive's Casino de Montbenon and the Renaissance-style Palais de Justice.
sources.shortName: Discover Lausanne’s most Photogenic Spots with a Local in Lausanne
Explore the Instaworthy Spots of Lausanne with a Local

places.name: Esplanade de Montbenon

reviews.text:
Fantastic place to have desserts and unwind for the evening.
(Although they could learn to brew a proper cup of tea). Nice mini desserts and nice gin selection
Beautiful place to walk around-peaceful, mostly quiet. Lots of benches around here.
Great place to chill and hang out, especially during sunset when it's golden hour!

places.generalDescription: Parc de Mon Repos is a serene 19th-century park nestled in Lausanne, offering a delightful escape into nature. This expansive green space is perfect for family outings, featuring playgrounds with swings and a sandpit complete with a water table that will keep the little ones entertained. The park also boasts an enchanting aviary where children can marvel at various exotic birds. With its lush trees and picturesque scenery, it's an ideal spot for leisurely strolls or relaxing picnics under the shade.

sources.snippet: This rambling English park is planted with exotic trees like giant sequoias and is all you need for a bit of repose. The layout that greets us today is from the first decades of the 19th century, when the French architect Louis-Emmanuel-Aimé Damesme reconfigured the park and its 18th-century villa. From 1922-1967 this building was where the IOC would sit.
sources.shortName: 15 Best Things to Do in Lausanne (Switzerland)

places.name: Parc de Mon Repos

reviews.text: A very lovely little park with small bird cages and a number of benches to take a break when visiting Lausanne.
Free of Charged , beautiful flowers . 25 March 2025.

This is hands down the most beautiful cherry blossom spot in Switzerland, it's definitely my favourite. My favourite thing to do is to organise a spring picnic, it feels like you're teleported to Japan for hanami!! The closest entrance to these trees are right beside piscine de mon repos!

places.generalDescription: Perched atop a hill in Sauvabelin Park, the Sauvabelin Tower offers visitors an unforgettable experience with its 302-step spiral staircase leading to a viewing platform. This impressive 35-meter wooden tower provides panoramic vistas of Lausanne and its surroundings, including Lake Geneva, the Swiss Alps, and the Jura region. Originally built in 2003 to replace the original tower from 1904, it stands as a symbol of the turn of the millennium.

sources.snippet: As the sun sets over the enchanting Ouchy Promenade, visitors can elevate their experience and take in the breathtaking beauty of Lausanne from above at the Sauvabelin Tower. This impressive tower, with its rich history and stunning architecture, offers panoramic vistas that will leave visitors in awe. Built in 2003 to replace the original wooden tower from 1904, the Sauvabelin Tower stands tall at 35 meters high and provides a 360-degree view of the city and its surroundings.
sources.shortName: Discover Lausanne'S Most Photogenic Spots With A Local

sources.snippet: The best place to catch sight of the beauty of Laussane, Sauvabelin Tower, is a wooden tower that offers a 360-degree view of the town, Lake Geneva, the Swiss Alps, and the Jura region, Eastern France. Constructed in 2003 by Julius Natterer, the 35-meter tall tower features a spiral staircase with 302 steps and an observation platform.
sources.shortName: Top 12 Best Things to Do in Lausanne, Switzerland

sources.snippet: For all the adrenaline enthusiasts visiting Lausanne, the city has something special for you too. Located in the nearby Sauvabelin forest, the Sauvabelin tower is a 35-meter high tower that was built in 2003. The tower has a 360-degree view, from which you can observe the city and many of its monuments.
sources.shortName: 15 Best Things To Do in Lausanne, Switzerland

sources.snippet: Located in the hills on the outskirts of Lausanne is Sauvabelin Tower. For sweeping views over Lausanne and Lake Geneva, climb the twisting staircase to the top of the tower. The tower is free to visit.
sources.shortName: Top Ten Things to do in Lausanne, Switzerland

sources.snippet: The structure is located outside the city limits, and towers in a park area. The tower, made of wood only fifteen years ago, can be reached by bus. The height of Sowabelen is 35 meters.
sources.shortName: Top 21 places to visit in Lausanne in 2024 (Lots of photos)

places.name: Sauvabelin Tower

reviews.text: I have lived in the Lausanne region for the past 30 years but this was the first time I climbed this tower, built entirely out of wood and financed by donors who can enjoy to have their names advertised on each step. There was a violent and ice cold "bise noir" blowing from NW this Sunday mid September of 2024 so I was almost alone on the viewing platform. Access and exit are via a metal gate being activated by pressing a button, something not really evident to many of the visitors. In the warm season access is possible all day till 6 p.m. There is a fantastic view over Lausanne, its suburbs and the surrounding countryside, better than photos taken in the middle of the day with its flat light.
Beautifully designed and built structure. Great views of Lausanne and surrounding areas. Worth the hike up.

The wooden spiral staircase is impressive, and climbing to the top is absolutely worth it. Best part? It's completely free! From the top, you get a breathtaking 360° view of Lausanne, Lake Geneva, and the Alps on a clear day. Surrounded by forest, the walk to the tower is peaceful and refreshing. A perfect spot for nature lovers, photographers, or anyone looking to enjoy the city from above. Don't miss it!

places.generalDescription: Nestled in a stunning 19th-century manor, the Hermitage Foundation is a must-visit destination for art enthusiasts and culture seekers alike. Surrounded by picturesque gardens that offer breathtaking views of the mountains and lake, this museum showcases an ever-evolving collection of over 650 artworks. Since its inception in 1984, it has become home to significant pieces from renowned Impressionist and Post-Impressionist artists like Monet, Degas, Van Gogh, and many others.

sources.snippet: Instead, this museum features continually changing temporary exhibitions, so there is always something new to see here. The museum is located in an opulent manor house that was built in the mid 19th century. Not only is the museum a joy to visit but the views over Lake Geneva from here are wonderful.
sources.shortName: Top Ten Things to do in Lausanne, Switzerland

sources.snippet: Another must-visit museum for art fanatics, the Hermitage Foundation features changing exhibits in an elegant lakeside villa facing the beautiful Lake Geneva. The 19th-century mansion now serves as a fine arts exhibition facility and offers a beautifully landscaped park open to the public.
sources.shortName: Top 12 Best Things to Do in Lausanne, Switzerland

places.name: Hermitage Foundation

reviews.text:
I loved the place!
The impressionist exhibit was breathtaking! Thank you !

Since 2021, I have not missed any of the exhibitions. The villa is beautiful itself, and in surrounding you can enjoy a garden with a Lausanne and lake view.

I give one star less, because up to today I do not understand, why the description of the exhibition are only in French. There is plenty of space on the walls to add English or at least German. I usually help myself with a translator, but it does not work in the basement floor due to absence of mobile signal. There is a WiFi, but for password you have to go back to the cash desk, so my suggestion is to connect to WiFi when you buy tickets.

The shop is usually full of great books relevant to the exhibitions, again English or German versions are very rare.

Staff is super friendly. There are views from the villa to the lake, in one room you may sit and play chess. Same as there is a place where you can sit down with your children.

The exhibition space is large, do not underestimate time for basement level, it is the biggest :).

Yesterday, my friend and I visited a beautiful exhibition of Polish painters. We both really enjoyed it. The Hermitage itself has a stunning setting – the building, the garden with views of the mountains and Lausanne Cathedral all create a lovely atmosphere.
We went on a Thursday for the evening opening (6-9 PM), which we found both convenient and reasonably priced – 11 CHF per adult. On regular days, the museum closes at 6 PM, which isn't ideal for people who work during the day.
However, on other days (except Thursday), the entrance fee is 22 CHF, which I find too expensive – especially compared to other art galleries in Switzerland.
The restaurant next to the museum is also quite overpriced.

places.generalDescription: Nestled in the heart of Lausanne, Place de la Palud is a charming cobbled square that beautifully captures the essence of European al fresco life. This vibrant locale is home to a stunning 16th-century fountain adorned with a statue of justice, which adds historical flair to your visit. Every hour from 9 am to 7 pm, be sure to catch the delightful cuckoo clock performance that narrates tales from the Vaud region's rich history.

sources.snippet: The lake and surrounding mountains will tempt you with more places to visit. Hop a lake steamer to tour Chateau Chillon and ride the Rochers-de-Naye Railway to the precipitous Alpine gardens high above. Spend a day in neighboring Vevey and whet your appetite at the interactive exhibits in the Alimentarium, or get active by cycling along the shore on the Tour du Lac Léman path.
sources.shortName: Attractions & Things to Do in Lausanne

sources.snippet: A wedge-shaped pedestrian square in the centre of Lausanne, Place de la Palud is ruled by the 17th-century City Hall and old apartment buildings. On the ground floor the building’s arcade leads you to a passageway continuing through to Place de la Louve. On the east side of the square is the Fontaine de la Justice, started in the 1500s.
sources.shortName: 15 Best Things to Do in Lausanne (Switzerland)

sources.snippet: This cobbled square is located at the city’s center near the hill. It was built towards the end of the 9th century and served as an intersection. Besides being one of the oldest parts of the city, the square is also filled with shops, cafes, and other modern attractions, making it a favorite location for locals to meet and relax.
sources.shortName: 15 Best Things To Do in Lausanne, Switzerland

places.name: Place de la Palud

reviews.text: Great square, used to be my favorite place to go and take a walk, drink some coffee and enjoy the city vibe. If you're a tourist, definitely  the place to come visit at least once on your visit. Also fountain in the center of the square too. Great place and would love to come and enjoy my time here again, 100% recommend.

I caught métro line 2 from the main station. 2 stops and then as I walked to the Cathedral I found this place by coincidence as it was not part of my places to visit. It was a crowded place because a lot of people were selling vegetables, cheese and many other things. (Guess Saturdays are "market days"). Very picturesque.

In the heart in the Lausanne.  Surrounded by old historic buildings and picturesque little streets, the square is the place to feel the tourist pulse of the city.  Every round hour, little dancing dolls come out of the clock tower and create an additional experience with their performance.  A good place for a glass of wine or beer in the middle of the day you choose to tour Lausanne.

places.address: Pl. de la Palud 1, 1003 Lausanne, Switzerland

places.generalDescription: The Collection de l'Art Brut is a museum in Lausanne that showcases avant-garde artworks created by self-taught, outsider artists. Founded by French artist Jean Dubuffet, the museum's permanent and temporary exhibits feature over 1,000 works by individuals with no formal artistic training. The collection includes diverse pieces such as naive paintings, sculptures, masks, and various media creations.

sources.snippet: Up the slope, in the outbuildings of the 18th-century Château de Beaulieu is one of the definitive collections of Art Brut. Most of these works were gathered by Jean Dubuffet, founder of the movement. The pieces come from all sorts of backgrounds: There are children’s drawings, pieces of folk art and paintings by patients in psychiatric hospitals, but one uniting characteristic is that all the artists exhibited here were on the margins of the art world.
sources.shortName: 15 Best Things to Do in Lausanne (Switzerland)

sources.snippet: Drop by the Collection de I’Art Brut for art enthusiasts, an unusual museum that features unique artworks crafted by self-taught artists, prisoners, or marginalized individuals. The museum is housed in an 18th-century castle, Château de Beaulieu, exhibiting fascinating collections from paintings to artworks made from different materials.
sources.shortName: Top 12 Best Things to Do in Lausanne, Switzerland

sources.snippet: This museum contains works of art by “untrained” artists: criminals, psychiatric patients, and orphans. The artwork is imaginative, unconventional, and a bit bizarre. Website: Get updated hours and pricing here.
sources.shortName: Top Ten Things to do in Lausanne, Switzerland

places.name: Collection de l'Art Brut

reviews.text: This is most probably one of the world's most interesting museums devoted to "outsider art", produced by self-taught creators, often marginalized, many living in institutions or being inmates. Their histories told beside their art works is often touching, sometimes violent. The French artist Jean Dubuffet was the initiator of this museum being a collector of this art form himself and then donating his collection to Lausanne. Just now, early 2024, the museum features a special exhibition called Visages, "faces", from which I have chosen to present some photographs for the reader to enjoy.  The museum is discretely implanted facing the Lausanne congress center, somewhat off the center of town, and is surprisingly roomy. The works are beautifully curated. I find it a must to spend a couple of hours here for anyone interested in arts living in or visiting the Lausanne area.
Have always been fascinated by Art Brut and excited to see the original collection of the study's founder Jean Dubuffet!

Must see for art lovers! I didn't take a lot of pics, merely enjoyed and bought a book (supports!). In the USA, I guess we call this folk art? The collection is VERY diverse. The Art Brut is now one of my favorite museums in the world.

places.generalDescription: The Palais de Rumine is a 19th century palace with several museums, including a fine art, zoology and archaeology collections. The most prominent of these are the Gabriel de Rumine Museum of Fine Arts and the Musée Gabriel de Rumine of Zoology & Archaeology. The building is situated in the historic centre of Lausanne and is hard to miss.

sources.snippet: When the Russian aristocrat Gabriel de Rumine passed away he left a fortune to the city to build a public venue. The result is the Palais de Rumine, constructed at the turn of the century and with architecture borrowed from the Florentine Renaissance. You can find the palace on Place de la Riponne, and there are no fewer than five museums inside.
sources.shortName: 15 Best Things to Do in Lausanne (Switzerland)

sources.snippet: Lausanne is also a cultural mecca, and even its museums are worthy of the most beautiful Instagram pictures… A real treat for us. Go to the hall of the Palais de Rumine to get this super aesthetic shot!
sources.shortName: Lausanne’s best instagrammable locations – Lausanne Tourisme
12 Instagrammable places in Lausanne

places.name: Palais de Rumine

reviews.text: A free and nice museum in the center of Lausanne. The geology and the natural science sections are quite interesting.  It's a perfect place to stop by if it rains.

A great museum in the center of Lausanne with free admission. There are permanent exhibits in archeology, history, geology, paleontology, and taxidermy/biology.

The mineral room in the geology exhibit was a standout for me -- some exceptional specimens and very well displayed.

Stop by and enjoy the exhibits as well as the beautiful architecture of the palace.

This museum is free on the 1st Saturday of each month. I visited and liked the variety it offers. It's a 4 museum in 1. Each area for a different one.
In overall is great to spend some time seeing good taxidermy examples from beautiful birds to, mammals. There's a great massive white shark that will surprise you.
A lot of skeletons of different categories, butterflies and so on. On the other museums on the building they offer an interesting approach on the archeological history and on the cultural aspect of Lausanne. You can see some elements from Napoleon, some heritage pieces, coins, sculptures, etc.
you can see great examples of stones, cristals, and tons of specimens of the geology world.
You can easily spend 2 or 3 hours roaming around.

places.address: Pl. de la Riponne 6, 1005 Lausanne, Switzerland

places.generalDescription: Nestled in the vibrant arts district of Plateforme 10, the Musée de l'Elysée stands as a beacon for photography enthusiasts. This national and international museum is housed in a stunning building crafted by renowned Portuguese architects Aires Mateus, alongside other cultural institutions like the Cantonal Museum of Fine Arts. The museum's rich history includes influential directors such as Sam Stourdze and Tatyana Franck, who have both contributed significantly to its evolution.

sources.snippet: One of Europe’s great photography museums is in another elegant 18th-century mansion overlooking the lake. There are more than 100,000 photographs in these galleries, many produced with the earliest techniques: You can study daguerrotype , albumen and ambrotype prints and follow photography’s evolution right through to digital prints. Feted Swiss photographers like Ella Maillart and Nicolas Bouvier bequeathed their life’s collections to the museum.
sources.shortName: 15 Best Things to Do in Lausanne (Switzerland)

places.name: Musée de l'Elysée

reviews.text: Great spot to visit if you are interested in art and photography!
Interesting architecture and spatial to separate 2 museums

Small collection of interesting photographs with extended descriptions available in an additional brochure. It was free because it was the first Saturday of the month, which was a nice surprise 😊 The mudac museum was closed though.
Also, the coffee in the café on ground level is AMAZING! They also offer vegan milk alternatives (oat and rice) and the coffee is really affordable for Swiss standards☕

places.address: Pl. de la Gare 17, 1003 Lausanne, Switzerland

sources.snippet: While exploring the charming streets and historic buildings of Lausanne’s Old Town, visitors can continue their journey to Parc Du Denantou, a picturesque park that offers stunning views of Lake Geneva. Here are three reasons why Parc Du Denantou is a must-visit spot for photography enthusiasts:. Local photography tips: The park is a favorite among local photographers, who can provide valuable advice on capturing the best shots.
sources.shortName: Discover Lausanne'S Most Photogenic Spots With A Local

sources.snippet: Escape to the exotic at Denantou Park's magnificent Thai Pavilion, a stunning gift from Thailand to Lausanne, complete with a serene river backdrop.
sources.shortName: Discover Lausanne’s most Photogenic Spots with a Local in Lausanne

reviews.text: Some of my best memories here in the World Triathlon championships in 2006
Beautiful park with views of the lake and mountains. There are nice statues, fountains, a rustic children's playground, stately trees and a forested area near the stream.
The park is nice, especially the Thai pavilion that shines gold at sunset.

sources.snippet: The Cathedral again, yes, but from a completely different angle this time!. If you want a picture worthy of the greatest instagrammers, head off to the Parc de l’Hermitage located north of Lausanne. A true haven of peace, only a few minutes from downtown!.
sources.shortName: Lausanne’s best instagrammable locations – Lausanne Tourisme

reviews.text: Beautiful, quiet and huge. The park sits on a hill where you can reach via several ways, in or from outside the forest, with or without stairs. We tried different routes, enjoying nicely different views. It was a bit challenging for my small child. A marvelous garden before the museum. A playground is surrounded by old trees. A clean free toilet at the back of the restaurant.
Awesome park for walking with stunning views of the lake and mountains in the background.
Great place to walk around and enjoy the nice weather. The restaurant on the top of the hill, offers great Fondues.

places.generalDescription: Nestled in the heart of Lausanne, the Lausanne Botanical Garden is a serene oasis that beckons nature lovers and families alike. With its beautifully landscaped paths and elevated viewpoints offering stunning vistas of the city and Lake Geneva, this garden is a delightful escape from urban life. Home to an impressive collection of trees categorized by type, it serves as both an educational hub and a tranquil retreat for visitors eager to explore diverse plant species from around the globe.

sources.snippet: There are also organized guided tours through the world of herbs, trees and flowers for a fee. The attraction is considered unique: this botanical garden has the largest collection of all kinds of tropical vegetation and carnivorous plants. The opening date is the 19th century.
sources.shortName: Top 21 places to visit in Lausanne in 2024 (Lots of photos)

places.name: Lausanne Botanical Garden

reviews.text:
Most beautiful botanical garden I've been to! Love the way the plants go from terrestrial plant to plants from the alps the higher you go up the hill.

There are so many frogs and other wildlife I was able to observe. Perfect place to go relax and enjoy a nice day.
Free Admission so no complaints. Beautiful in Spring . I went early April.

A peaceful gem in the heart of Lausanne! It's not only beautifully maintained but also rich in biodiversity. It's a perfect place to take a break from the busy city.
I especially loved the small greenhouses and the stunning view over the city. Highly recommend for a relaxing and inspiring visit!
